title: Building A Computer Need Advice!

embed.description: Declan.88's Saved PCPartPicker Part List: AMD FX-8320, MSI Radeon R9 290, NZXT Phantom 240

body: Hey Guys I recently decided I wanted to build a computer since my current one is starting to lag behind all the others. The Items included in the build are an AMD FX-8320, MSI RADEON R9 290, NZXT PHANTOM 240. These are the parts that I chosen to use for gaming and just wanted to know what you guys think and if I should change anything?  *ThIs computer isn't just for league its for other games like Dayz, BF4 and the occasional video/photo editing **

replies.body: The reason why I chose the AMD it is a more affordable bang for buck processor compared to the intel series that tend to be around $50-$100 more expensive.

Yea that is a positive with the AMD's they are cheaper but that's like the only positive thing about them, i'd never get an AMD, i would've saved up some more money and got an Intel, an I5 is pretty much all you need which is what i have.
What combination of parts would you recommend keeping in mind that I am on a $1k Budget. (Like GPU and CPU wise)

My GPU is a GTX 750 Ti and CPU is Intel Core i5-3470 3.20GHz, keep in mind that i got this CPU around a year and a half ago so you would be able to get a better one than me now, when i first got my PC i got a GTX 650 though which was a very good GPU.

An i5 and a 700 series GPU is all you need to be able to play latest games on high-ultra settings and have a pretty fast computer, spending any more money is just a waste of money if you ask me, i7 is a rip off and anything beyond the 700 series is also a rip off, no need to spend more.

Personally, if you can afford Intel, go for Intel. Their processors are definitely much more efficient.
I have an AMD 8320 overclocked, and as much as I like it, compared to another machine with a nice intel i7 K series, the intel just about outperforms it on every front.

AMD also loves to suck power, so factor that into your build as well.
Also, why not go for something like the nVidia GTX 970, it's only a little bit more than the 290, but it smashes it. The 970 is probably the best bang for buck card currently on the market.

But it's your choice dude.

The reason why I chose the 290 over the 970 was because of the $85 Dollar difference and for the performance increase it is very little.  I have looked on various benchmarking sites and the frames difference in about 10 FPS more, This is why I don't think that it is worth spending the extra $80.

Fair call - from memory the AMD's use more power though, so that is also a thought. It may end up equating similar down the line if you are one that pays the power bills.. 

Essentially though, this is pure preference.
The nVidia cards have much better drivers in my experience. AMD drivers are dodgy at times I've found and can cause more issues than I really like. Other than though, they are solid cards when working.

I See where you are coming from but at the moment the prices for the AMD cards are quite a bit cheaper and the performance is still pretty good. I also haven't heard much about the drivers being bad since quite a lot of people go for the AMD option so I thought this would be a good idea for me as well considering I was going for a Red and Black Themed Build.

Absolutely, bang for buck the AMD cards are decent.
But the drivers are a bit iffy at times, much better than they used to be that's for damn sure.

It's purely preference dude.
I'm running an AMD 8320 and R9 280X currently, it goes fine.
I just feel I had a better experience with my i5 K series and GTX 670

But like I said, it's all preference.
Well my budget is around $1000-$1100 so if you have any time would you consider making a nvidea/Intel build that would have the same performance as this? Thanks for the help so farðŸ˜ƒ

I'm sure I could put something together...
I guess the question is, do you need a case, and peripherals?

I think $1500 is a sweet spot for a mid-range gaming build.

Similar to this: http://www.pccasegear.com/sc/q67

You can obviously swap and change things as you'd personally prefer or find necessary. Such as different parts to fit a colour scheme you may want.

Well yeah I was going for a Red and Black themed build. The Only problem I have with the 970 is that it is around $100 more expensive than the 290 and the performance is a tiny increase hence why I am hesitant to make the switch.

You're always welcome to put a 290 in there.
It'll still work just fine on an intel board. I just suggest the intel processor over the AMD processor/chipset.

Just gotta remember you get what you pay for :)
Always buy the most expensive parts, so you can whip out your e-peen is spec threads. My PC is 3 years old and still can run all modern games on Ultra, best $3,000 ever spent.
{{champion:6}} to be kidding me! Did you really spend $3000 on a computer for League of Legends or do you do high end gaming and video/photo editing?

> {{champion:6}} to be kidding me! Did you really spend $3000 on a computer for League of Legends or do you do high end gaming and video/photo editing?

Aha! Nah, I play a various amount of games, I don't really play League as much as I used to, at the time I needed the PC for music, however upgraded it for future games, best parts at the time, I think it will last another 2 years if I must drop down to high it's still good. In the long run buying better parts saves you money.
I think now days you can spend around $1k and get a really good rig. If I spent $3k I could get a build with 3x 780ti's with a top of the line Intel i7 processor :D
